title: Tamar Estuary - Saltash Walk Route

images.title: Tony Atkin / Saltash Foreshore
images.caption: Saltash Foreshore. Low tide on the Tamar Estuary.

images.title: John Rostron / Tamar bridges from Saltash
images.caption: Tamar bridges from Saltash. Just before the bridges, the railway skirts close to the estuary, allowing you to hang out of the window to grab a photograph. From this viewpoint (SSW), the railway bridge is in front of the road bridge.

images.title: Tony Atkin / Saltmill Creek meets the Tamar Estuary
images.caption: Saltmill Creek meets the Tamar Estuary This small triangle of marshland is all that is left of what must have been a marshy area covering the whole of Saltmill Park before it was used as a rubbish dump and then converted to parkland.

images.title: Derek Harper / Coombe Park, Saltash
images.caption: Coombe Park. Babis Lane swings across the Coombe valley at the head of Coombe Creek, and passes Coombe Park, a small cul-de-sac of modern houses. Just before the bridge, a footpath heads off left into the woods and up the valley.

images.title: Derek Harper / Chichester Crescent, Saltash
images.caption: Chichester Crescent. Housing drops down the hill towards the valley behind Coombe Viaduct. Across the valley are buildings on Higher Port View, including St Barnabas Hospital.

images.title: Gwyn Jones / River Tamar at Saltash
images.caption: River Tamar. The river has many moods depending on the seasons, as can be seen in this scene looking across the river from the quay, to Saltash Passage within early morning light.

images.title: Derek Harper / Coombe Viaduct from Barne Barton
images.caption: Coombe Viaduct from Barne Barton. Looking across the River Tamar to Saltash from Foulston Avenue.

images.title: Derek Harper / Railway Bridge, Wearde Road
images.caption: Railway Bridge, Wearde Road. Wearde Road has become a track carrying bridleway 636/26/1 since the lane to Wearde Quay turned away from it; after crossing this bridge over the Oaddinton-Penzance line it becomes a rather muddy one. The notice proclaims Churchtown Farm Community Nature Reserve. In the background is the River Lynher.

description: Explore the Tamar Estuary Nature Reserve on this short walk near Saltash. The reserve is located a couple of miles north of Saltash. You can follow a footpath along the estuary from Cargreen to Landulph. Look out for wildlife including avocet, shelduck and large numbers of waders. You can see a great view of the estuary at Cargreen using the google street view link below. It's a lovely spot with lots of sailboats and the Cornish countryside in the background. To explore the beautiful Tamar Valley further you can pick up the Tamar Valley Discovery Trail and visit the lovely Lopwell Dam Nature Reserve.
